description.narrative: The Second Economic Competitiveness Support Program Development Policy Loan for the Kingdom of Morocco is the second Development Policy Loan (DPL) in a programmatic series of two single-tranche DPLs. The program development objective of the Second Economic Competitiveness Support Program (ECSP II) is to support policy reforms in three key areas of the Government’s comprehensive economic strategy: (a) Improving the investment climate; (b) Furthering trade policy reform and trade facilitation; and (c) Strengthening economic governance. These key areas are referred to as pillars. Pillar 1 focuses on four key dimensions to improve Morocco’s business climate: Enhancing e-governance for regulatory and administrative simplification; Simplifying administrative procedures and improving transparency; Reducing the financial burden on SMEs resulting from excessive payment delays; and modernizing the legal framework for entry and governance of corporations under SA status. Pillar 2 involves infrastructure investments in roads and ports have increased significantly, customs procedures have been streamlined as well as ports procedures; an online trade platform has been implemented by the customs administration; services liberalization has been successfully implemented in the civil aviation area and to a lesser extent, in the commercial shipping sector and logistics. Pillar 3 focuses on three essential aspects of economic governance: (a) Assessing costs and benefits of incentives granted by the Commission for Investments, (b) Improving the public private coordination for business environment reforms, and (c) Strengthening the institutional framework for the competition.

title.narrative: Rationalization of tariff structure on imports through a reduction of maximum tariff quota applicable to industrial products.
Number of limited liabaility companies (SARL) formally registered.
Assessment of costs and benefits grantes to investment projects is included in the annual activity report of the National Commission for Investments
Companies are reporting in their certified accounts their average payment delays as per the new regulations.
Petitions requesting the application of anti-dumping, anti-subsidy or safeguard measures are formally processed and published according to WTO rules and procedures
Reduction in average transit time for goods at Casablanca airport.
Number of investment climate reforms accounted for in the Doing Business survey between 2013-2015 that have been initiated and coordinated by the National Committee for Business Environment.
Reduction of the formalities and duration for registering property for business
Percentage of products put on the market that are randomly controlled which complies with new security requirements
Improvement in the Doing Business indicator "protecting minority investor"
Number of investigations formerly launched by the Competition Council under the new legal and regulatory framework
Number of simplifications and standardisations of administrative procedures made public on the governement website service-public.ma
Reduction by at least ten percent in average payment delay in sector where average payment delays is over 100 days.
All newly created corporations identified through a unique business identification code
